THE PRINCE ALBERT TIMES
AND
SASKATCHEWAN REVIEW

SPINK & MAVEETY

PRINCE ALBERT, N.W.T.

THE MUNICIPALITY ORDINANCE

We have now an opportunity to make a somewhat hasty report of the bill which was passed at the recent meeting of the North West Council in regard to the incorporation of a new municipality. It is a matter of vital importance to this community, we give our readers a synopsis of its principal provisions:

1. The municipality will consist of two townships, each containing not less than five hundred acres of land, making a total area of one thousand acres.

2. The municipality will be known as "Prince Albert."

3. The municipality will be governed by a council consisting of three members elected by the voters.

4. The municipality will levy taxes to provide for the maintenance of roads, bridges, and other public works.

5. The municipality will be responsible for the care of the poor and the maintenance of a hospital.

6. The municipality will be entitled to receive grants from the Dominion government for the construction of public buildings.

7. The municipality will be subject to the jurisdiction of the North West Council.

The ordinance will be submitted to the Legislative Assembly for approval.

NO IRISH NEED APPLY

CHARITY.

To the Editor of The Times,

Sir,-A person who is without means or property, who has been reduced to the necessity of begging, and who is unable to earn his living by honest labor, should be encouraged to seek charity. The poor are entitled to assistance from those who are able to give it.

D. J. MAGUIRE.

Prince Albert District, N.W.T.
October 31, 1883.

DIED IN THE FAITH.

The Prophet of a Life in Which There Was No Room for Doubt and No Sunshine.

When the meeting was over, the Lord said to me, "Go back to your home and tell your family about the death of Uncle Daniel." I went back to my home and told my family about Uncle Daniel's death. They were very sad and cried. I knew that Uncle Daniel had died in the faith.

BEATEN AT HIS OWN GAME.

The local article of confidence man is quite mysterious in his way, but hardly yet, to the astonishment of the scientific members of the fraternity was rapidly arriving from New York and Chicago to gather in the country visitor crop.

Last Wednesday, as the overnight train was disgorging its passengers in the Union depot, a pale and looking young man walked into the gray coat storekeeper who was staring open-mouthed around him, and clasped him fervently by the hand.

"Why, why do you do, Mr. Goffy?"

"I thought you knew my name was Goffy," said the delegate from the foothills, who immediately and distinctly obtruded that "Jas. Goffy, Vaish," was painted in big letters on the valise he carried in his hand.

"Well, Jas., old man, you can't have forgotten me, Mr. Sanders—your old friend. How are all the boys in Idaho?"

"Think you see yer, glad yer see yer. I've got a present for yer bad memory, but seeing as how yer here, yer may have somethin', and the gangster."

"Of course you do. Coming down for a little look at the old sights. I'm going to pay you a visit. I'll see you after dinner, and we'll take a walk on the valley together. Here's my address."

"Thank you, thank you, my boy," and the hayseed party much affected. "There's the first kind words I've heard since Left home, and, with the most natural of his simple, hearty manner, took the young man in his arms and hugged him. Then, going where to meet later, he shuffled along.

That afternoon the plausible young man was down at headquarters complaining that his watch had been robbed of its watch and pocketed by a "bootlegger" up as an old granger.

"There wasn't nothing particular in them, but they was worth something," explained, "and the watch was cruel, but I'm blessed if I want to be beat at my own game." Pooh!

PROSPECTUS OF THE Prince Albert Directory AND BUSINESS GUIDE.

It is proposed to issue a Business Directory for the Town of Prince Albert and Districts of Lloyd and Lorne which will contain the advertisements of each business establishment, (to be in serial order at separate rate) and a descriptive notice of each place.

The prospectus will contain a history of Prince Albert, its present condition and future prospects, together with a statement of this year's crops, etc., so that they can be accounted for the District of Lorne, extent of acreage, number of cattle, sheep, etc., increase over last year's crop, population of District, and other useful information, written by well known writers.

About 500 or more copies will be published according to the encouragement received, and distributed throughout the Dominion and the Mother Country.

It is hoped that by this means, benefits will result, not only to each individual advertiser and subscriber, but that the whole country will benefit thereby and appreciate what has been done abroad and a healthy emigration encouraged to this country.

Price of advertisement, whole page, with notice on opposite page, $10; two copies gratis. Single copies, 50c.

CHIT-CHAT LOCALS.

Gathered by our Reporters.

Fresh News.

O. H. Hughes & Co., have driven in 25 new wagons from their yard. They have been out and can now supply beef at very reasonable rates, by the quarter or otherwise.

Appointments.

The Board of Commissioners has appointed the Rev. John Hardwick, his late chaplain, Chaplain-in-Chief, in England, to become Secretary-Chaplain of the Province of Saskatchewan.

Grand Views.

It is stated that the Department of the Interior will shortly make an effort to settle all the old settlers claims against the Government, but it is not known when the final settlement will be made. A good deal of correspondence has been exchanged in this connection. It was thought that the settlement would be made last fall, but Mr. Lindsay Russell finally adjourned them last summer, but that government officials have been unable to settle the matter. We are told that Mr. Lindsay Russell is still unable to settle the matter. We are told that Mr. Lindsay Russell is still unable to settle the matter.

Arrival of the New Governor-General.

The Marquis of Lorne, the new Governor-General of the Dominion, will arrive here early next week. He will be received by His Excellency the Governor-General of Canada and after having been sworn in by Lord Lorne in the presence of the Cabinet, Mr. Macdonald, the Prime Minister, will preside over the Court, proceeded by special train to Ottawa where they were officially received by the Governor-General. The Marquis of Lorne will be sworn into office on December 1st.

Changes in the Cabinet.

As the new Governor-General, Sir John Macdonald has resigned the Ministry of the Interior. He was succeeded by Hon. Senator McPherson. The Ministry of the Interior will now be under the supervision of the Indian and Police Departments. Hon. Senator McPherson was for the last few months the Minister practically acting as Minister of the Interior has been sworn in as Minister of the Interior. He will be sworn into office from the Speakership of the Senate and which position Senator Miller of Nova Scotia holds. Hon. Senator McPherson is one of the ablest debaters and one of the most powerful speakers in the Senate. He has been a member of the Senate for many years and has been a great friend of the government since Confederation. We are glad to see him in the Senate again and we hope he will continue to serve the country.

The Recreation Rooms.

The recreation rooms of the rooms of the club, in the building, will take place this evening, and at the same time the opening address will be given by the Secretary. The Committee have prepared a literary and musical programme, comprising readings, songs, and music. The programme will be a large success and a good collection will be taken up towards the upkeep of the club. There are great advantages in joining the club and we urge all who are interested to join.

The Women's Work.

The Women's Work is doing good work. The ladies, who are members of the club, are engaged in various charitable works. They are doing good work and we urge all members to join.

The Regina Leader.

The Regina Leader is doing good work. The paper is doing good work and we urge all members to join.
